title: First black woman to receive Booker Prize describes joint win as ‘bittersweet’
text:
Margaret Atwood and Bernardine Evaristo were jointly awarded the prize (Picture: Getty Images)

The first black woman to win the Man Booker Prize has described her victory as ‘bittersweet’.

Bernardine Evaristo, 60, author of Girl, Woman, Other, was given the award jointly with Margaret Atwood, whose novel The Testaments was released this year.

Speaking after the prize ceremony at the Guildhall in London, she said it was ‘incredible’ to be given the prize as a ‘black woman writing about black British women’.

She continued: ‘It’s a bittersweet experience. In one sense it’s great to be the first, but I shouldn’t be the first.

‘I think this prize has moved with the times. Our culture has moved somewhat in the past few years.’

The judges said they ‘couldn’t separate’ the two books (Picture: Getty Images)

She added: ‘I don’t think it would have happened five years ago or ten years ago. I think it’s about how the prize is won and who gets to be the judges.

‘It just has not gone to black people, hardly at all. Hopefully it will inspire people. Hopefully I will be a role model, especially to writers of colour.’

Evaristo’s win also makes her the first black British author to win the prize since it began in 1969.

While Atwood, who also received the prize in 2000 for novel The Blind Assassin, is now the award’s oldest winner at 79.

The Handmaid’s Tale author said she would have been ’embarrassed’ to win the award alone at her age.

They will share the £50,000 prize money (Picture: Getty Images)

She said: ‘I have been on many a jury and I’ve been on a jury where we’ve split the prize. I understand the predicament. I get it.

‘In a perfect world, which is the world of Alice In Wonderland, all have won and all shall have prizes.’

Evaristo and Atwood will share the £50,000 prize money between them.

The Booker has been split twice before, between Nadine Gordimer and Stanley Middleton in 1974, and again between Michael Ondaatje and Barry Unsworth in 1992

Rules were brought in following this to prevent future divisions of the prize, but the judges insisted they ‘couldn’t separate’ the two works.

description: Bernardine Evaristo became the first black author to win the Booker Prize, awarded jointly with author Margaret Atwood.
